abstract.p: Futures markets provide an effective way to hedge financial exposure. Deciding upon the appropriate number of contracts to buy or sell is easy if a contract is traded in exactly the same commodity and with exactly the same maturity as the exposure that is to be hedged. However, if an exact offset is not possible a partial reduction in risk may still be accomplished. Finding the best such hedge requires knowledge about the way futures prices vary with the underlying risk. In this paper we formulate the best-hedge-ratio problem in a non-parametric framework, and show that although the hedge ratio is the solution to a certain least-squares problem, it is not a regression coefficient in the usual sense. We contrast our approach with, and discuss the limitations of, the parametric models for hedge-ratio estimation that have appeared in the literature. We also discuss the implications of our results for practice.
